studies and serum carboxyhemoglobin measurement for all patients with neurologic changes, dyspnea, chest pain, or smoke exposure.
A carboxyhemoglobin level >25% in any patient is diagnostic of severe acute carbon monoxide poisoning.
Pulse oximetry data are unreliable because the oximeter is unable to differentiate carboxyhemoglobin from oxyhemoglobin.

Normobaric oxygen therapy is the treatment of choice. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated for patients with severe carbon monoxide poisoning (characterized by loss of consciousness and persistent neurologic deficits), patients who are pregnant, or patients with evidence of cardiac ischemia.
